This study investigated the effects of dealumination on Pd/SSZ-13 catalysts for methane combustion. Pd(1)/SSZ-13 (HTA), prepared by treating the catalyst hydrothermally at 750 °C, displayed extremely low catalytic activity. In contrast, Pd(1)/SSZ-13 (DeAl), prepared by treating the SSZ-13 support hydrothermally followed by Pd impregnation, exhibited superior catalytic activity for methane oxidation. Catalytic properties, including zeolite hydrophobicity and Pd location and states, were investigated by using various characterization techniques to clarify the differences between the catalysts. Most Pd species in the Pd/SSZ-13 (HTA) catalyst existed as Pd ions, which were not very active for the reaction. On the contrary, most Pd species in the Pd(1)/SSZ-13 (DeAl) catalyst existed as PdO nanoparticles at the external surface, which were highly active for methane oxidation. The study results suggested that the amount of external PdO nanoparticles should be maximized in order to make Pd/SSZ-13 catalyst highly active for methane combustion, which was achieved by dealuminating the SSZ-13 support before Pd impregnation. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords CH4 oxidation Pd/SSZ-13 Hydrothermal treatment Dealumination Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Shale gas revolution has led to a rapid increase in the global natural gas production in the past few decades. [1]. As natural gas emits fewer pollutants, it is considered a cleaner energy source compared to other fossil fuels [2]. Therefore, the number of vehicles running on liquefied natural gas (LNG) is continuously increasing [3]. However, methane slip, which occurs when methane escapes unburnt from LNG engines, is a serious environmental problem, because the global warming potential of methane is 25 times higher than that of CO2 [4]. The most efficient method for eliminating methane from the exhaust gas is complete oxidation of methane to CO2. However, methane is an inert chemical because of its high symmetry and low polarizability [5]. Therefore, active catalysts are required to oxidize methane at low temperatures and save energy. Supported Pd catalysts are accepted as the most active ones for the methane-combustion reaction [6]. However, Pd catalysts are vulnerable to sintering and deactivation by water in the exhaust gas, which is known to severely inhibit the initial activity and cause deactivation of the catalyst, thereby hindering the long-term operation of the catalyst [7]. A possible method to synthesize a water-resistant catalyst is to use a hydrophobic support. Zeolite can be an effective support for the methane-oxidation catalyst because its hydrophobicity can be enhanced by increasing the Si/Al2 ratio [8]. Zeolites can be easily dealuminated by steam treatment at high temperatures, also called the hydrothermal treatment [9]. The effects of hydrothermal aging on the catalytic activities of Pd/zeolite catalysts have been studied by various groups. Wang et al. reported that CO oxidation activity and NOx-storage capacity of the Pd/SSZ-13 catalyst decreased after thermal aging under harsh conditions (900 °C) [10]. They claimed that severe damage to the SSZ-13 structure and sintering of bulk PdOx particles on the zeolite surface are responsible for the activity loss. On the contrary, our group reported that the NOx-storage ability and CO oxidation activity of the Pd/SSZ-13 catalyst can be enhanced by the hydrothermal treatment at 750 °C [8]. The hydrophobic zeolite exhibited a higher NOx-storage capacity in the presence of H2O because the concentration of dehydrated Pd ions increased after dealumination. However, to the best of our knowledge, very few studies have investigated the effects of hydrothermal treatment on the methane-oxidation activity of Pd/zeolite catalysts. This study attempts to investigate the methane-oxidation reaction of the Pd/SSZ-13 catalyst and improve its activity by dealumination. The study employs various characterization techniques to elucidate the change in the catalytic activity after dealumination. 2 Materials and methods 2.1 Preparation of catalysts Because PdO is accepted as the active phase for methane oxidation, all Pd/SSZ-13 catalysts were prepared by using the incipient wetness impregnation (IWI) method instead of the ion-exchange method [11]. First, Pd was impregnated on H-SSZ-13 (Si/Al2 = 23, Heesung Catalysts) using Pd(NO3)2·2H2O (Sigma Aldrich) by the IWI method with a Pd loading of 1 wt%. After the impregnation, the catalyst was dried at 80 °C overnight and calcined at 500 °C under static condition (dry air) for 2 h. The as-made catalyst was denoted as Pd(1)/SSZ-13. To study the effects of dealumination, the Pd(1)/SSZ-13 (HTA) catalyst was prepared by treating the Pd(1)/SSZ-13 catalyst at 750 °C for 20 h in the presence of 10 % H2O and 15 % O2 (N2 balance). However, our previous studies revealed that the hydrothermal treatment can disintegrate PdO nanoparticles to isolated Pd ions, which are less active in the methane-combustion reaction [8,12]. Therefore, another catalyst was prepared by using a slightly different method. First, H-SSZ-13 was hydrothermally aged under the same conditions described earlier. Then, Pd was impregnated on dealuminated H-SSZ-13 by the IWI method with a Pd loading of 1 wt%. The catalyst was dried at 80 °C overnight and calcined at 500 °C under static condition (dry air) for 2 h. The as-made catalyst was denoted as Pd(1)/SSZ-13 (DeAl). Pd(1)/Al2O3, which is one of the most common catalysts for the methane combustion reaction, was also prepared for the purpose of comparison [13]. First, Pd was impregnated on Al2O3 (PURALOX) by the IWI method with a Pd loading of 1 wt%. The catalyst was dried at 80 °C overnight and calcined at 500 °C under static condition (dry air) for 2 h. 2.2 Catalyst characterization The textural properties of the samples were examined by solid-state magic angle spinning nuclear magnetic resonance (MAS NMR), N2 adsorption–desorption, and X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis. Solid-state 27Al and 29Si MAS NMR experiments were conducted using 500-MHz Bruker Avance III HD (Bruker, German) at room temperature. 4-mm MAS probe at a spinning rate of 10 kHz was used to measure the data. N2 adsorption–desorption experiments were conducted using BELSORP-mini II (BEL Japan). The samples were degassed at 200 °C for 3 h under vacuum to eliminate the adsorbed impurities from the catalysts. The specific surface areas were calculated using the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) equation, while the micropore volumes were obtained from the t-plot. XRD analysis was carried out on a SmartLab (Rigaku) system (30 mA, 40 kV). The hydrophobicity of the catalysts was examined by thermogravimetric analysis (TGA), H2O adsorption isotherms, and diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (DRIFTS). TGA analysis was conducted using a Discovery TGA (TA Instruments) apparatus to quantify the amount of desorbed H2O. The temperature was increased to 500 °C under air (5 °C/min)·H2O adsorption isotherms were obtained using a 3Flex Adsorption Analyzer (Micrometrics). The samples were pretreated under N2 at 300 °C for 4 h to eliminate impurities. After cooling down to 40 °C, water vapor was dosed gradually until the pressure reached up to 0.45 P/P0. DRIFTS experiments were performed in a diffuse reflectance cell (Praying Mantis, Harrick) installed in a Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectrometer (iS-50, Thermo Fisher Scientific) with an MCT detector (32 scans, resolution of 4 cm−1). The pretreatment was conducted to eliminate any impurities with 50 mL/min of N2 at 300 °C for 1 h·H2O adsorption was conducted at 120 °C with 5 mL/min of H2O for 30 min, which was 10 % of the total flowrate balanced with N2. The DRIFT spectra were collected at 120 °C after N2 purging for 30 min The Pd state was characterized by Raman analysis, DRIFTS, H2 temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR), and NH3 temperature programmed desorption (NH3-TPD). Raman spectra were obtained from Raman spectrometer Ⅱ (DXR2xi) with the samples excited at 532 nm. The DRIFTS spectra were collected after pretreating the samples under N2 at 300 °C for 1 h. Every sample was saturated with CO molecules at 50 °C for 30 min, followed by N2 purging at 50 °C for another 30 min. The DRIFTS spectra were obtained by subtracting the background spectra collected before the sample was saturated with CO molecules. H2-TPR was operated on a BELCAT II system. The pretreatment was conducted before completing the analysis with 50 mL/min of Ar at 300 °C. H2-TPR profiles were obtained by elevating the temperature from −80 to 300 °C with 30 mL/min of 5 % H2, balanced with Ar (10 °C/min). NH3-TPD was operated on a BELCAT B system. Pretreatment was conducted at 300 °C for 1 h in He gas, which was then cooled to 50 °C. NH3 adsorption was conducted with 10 % NH3, balanced with He. After removing the physically adsorbed NH3 by flowing He gas at 100 °C for 1 h, NH3-TPD profiles were obtained by elevating the temperature up to 700 °C under He gas. The Pd location was characterized by high-angle annular dark-field scanning transmission electron microscopy (HAADF-STEM) and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). HAADF-STEM was conducted on JEM-ARM200F (JEOL) with a spherical aberration corrector (200 kV). XPS was operated on a K-alpha spectrometer (Thermo Fischer Scientific). The C 1 s reference peak (284.6 eV) was utilized to correct the binding energies. 2.3 Catalytic reaction system The catalytic activity measurements of the prepared catalysts were carried out in a quartz reactor. The mixture of catalysts and SiO2 beads at a ratio of 1:2 was used to disperse the heat generated from the reaction. The inlet feed was a mixture of 1000 ppm of CH4, 15 % O2, 5 % H2O, and N2 balance (60,000 mL/gcat·h). The outlet feed gas composition was analyzed via online gas chromatography (Younglin 6500) with a thermal conductivity detector and a flame ionization detector. The conversion of CH4 was determined after stabilization for 30 min from 300° to 450°C at 25 °C intervals, and it was calculated using the following Eq. (1): (1) CH 4 conversion ( % ) = CH 4 , inlet − CH 4 , outlet CH 4 , inlet × 100 % To compare deactivation rates of catalysts during methane combustion reaction, we measured the deactivation rate of catalysts based on the normalized activity where the initial CH4 conversion is denoted as 1. CH4 conversion of catalysts would decrease following the reaction time, and its decreasing slope of the normalized activity was calculated as a deactivation rate by using a linear fitting in Origin Software. 3 Results 3.1 Catalytic activity The effects of dealumination on the Pd/SSZ-13 catalysts were investigated using three different catalysts: Pd(1)/SSZ-13 (pristine catalyst), Pd(1)/SSZ-13 (HTA) (prepared by hydrothermal treatment of the pristine catalyst), and Pd(1)/SSZ-13 (DeAl) (prepared by hydrothermal treatment of the SSZ-13 support, followed by Pd impregnation). Methane combustion was evaluated with these prepared Pd/SSZ-13 catalysts. Pd(1)/SSZ-13 (HTA) exhibited extremely low activity compared to that demonstrated by the other catalysts; it could not oxidize methane at temperatures lower than 450 °C ( Fig. 1). In contrast, Pd(1)/SSZ-13 (DeAl) exhibited the highest activity among the Pd/SSZ-13 catalysts. The T 50 of Pd(1)/SSZ-13 (DeAl) was 386 °C, lower than that of the pristine catalyst by 23 °C ( Table 1). Moreover, its catalytic activity was superior to that of Pd(1)/Al2O3, which is the most common catalyst for the methane-oxidation reaction owing to its high thermal stability and mechanical strength [13]. However, these results indicate that the hydrothermal treatment is not always beneficial to the methane-oxidation activity; Pd should be impregnated after hydrothermally treating the zeolite support in order to synthesize a highly active catalyst for methane combustion. To explain the change in catalytic activity after the hydrothermal treatment, the catalysts were extensively investigated via various characterization methods. 3.2 Catalyst characterization First, dealumination of the zeolite support after the hydrothermal treatment was verified by solid-state NMR analysis. The Al species in the zeolite can be analyzed from 27Al NMR spectra ( Fig. 2a). The main peak at approximately 59 ppm can be assigned to tetrahedrally coordinated Al (framework Al), while other peaks at 30 ppm, and 0 ppm are attributed to the penta-coordinated Al and octahedrally coordinated Al (extra-framework Al), respectively [14]. Both Pd(1)/SSZ-13 (DeAl) and Pd(1)/SSZ-13 (HTA) showed a sharp decrease in the tetrahedrally coordinated Al peak compared to the pristine catalyst, indicating that the framework Al species was eliminated during the aging. In addition, a slight increase in the extra-framework Al peak was observed after the hydrothermal treatment, implying the generation of a defective framework after dealumination [15]. The Si species in the zeolite catalysts were examined by using 29Si NMR analysis (Fig. 2b). The main peak at approximately −111 ppm is attributed to Q4 Si(O-Si)4. Another peak at −105 ppm belongs to Q3 Si(O-Si)3(O-Al) [14]. The intensity of Q4 peak of Pd(1)/SSZ-13 (HTA) was not significantly different from that of the pristine catalyst, while that of Pd(1)/SSZ-13 (DeAl) showed a sharp increase. However, a clear decrease in the Q3 peak intensity was observed for both Pd(1)/SSZ-13 (DeAl) and Pd(1)/SSZ-13 (HTA) compared to the pristine catalyst, implying that the decrease in the Al species of the zeolite framework occurred regardless of the order of Pd impregnation and hydrothermal treatment processes. Second, the textural properties of Pd/SSZ-13 catalysts were explored by N2 adsorption–desorption and XRD analyses. A sharp slope was observed from the N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms at low pressures, suggesting the presence of micropores (Fig. S1). In addition, the hysteresis loop indicates the presence of mesopores, which arises from the stacking of zeolite particles [16]. Nevertheless, there was no noticeable difference in the N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms of the catalysts. The specific surface area (562 vs. 582 cm2/g) and micropore volume (0.32 vs. 0.32 cm3/g) of the catalysts were also similar, which indicate that the zeolite microporous structure was not destroyed by the dealumination process (Table S1). Meanwhile, the XRD patterns showed that the SSZ-13 support in all catalysts had the chabazite structure, demonstrating a stable zeolite structure (Fig. S2) [17]. The relative crystallinity of the SSZ-13 support was calculated from the ratio of the main peak intensity (9°), which was 96 % of that of Pd(1)/SSZ-13 (DeAl) [18]. The characterization results showed that the zeolite structure was maintained, although the aluminum species were selectively eliminated during the hydrothermal treatment. Hydrophobicity of the zeolite can be enhanced by dealumination. The change in hydrophobicity after the hydrothermal treatment was explored by TGA, H2O adsorption, and H2O-DRIFTS analyses. Because the catalysts were calcined at 500 °C before conducting the TGA analysis, the weight loss observed during the experiment can be considered as the desorption of adsorbed H2O on the zeolite support (Fig. S3). The relatively small weight loss observed from the Pd(1)/SSZ-13 (DeAl) catalyst indicates that it is more hydrophobic than the pristine catalyst. The H2O adsorption isotherms show the adsorption of a larger amount of H2O, which further supports that the zeolite became more hydrophobic after dealumination (Fig. S4). The change in hydrophobicity was further confirmed from the DRIFTS spectra, which were collected after H2O adsorption and subsequent N2 purging (Fig. S5). The broad band from 2800 to 3500 cm−1 can be ascribed to the OH stretching vibration of the adsorbed water [19]. The OH band was hardly observed from Pd(1)/SSZ-13 (DeAl), implying that it became more hydrophobic after dealumination, which is compatible with the previous characterization results. The increase in hydrophobicity can be explained by the characteristics of Al-O-Si and Si-O-Si bonds in the zeolite. The Al-O-Si bond is more polar than the Si-O-Si bond because Al-O comprises both covalent and ionic bonds, while Si-O is a completely covalent bond. Considering that H2O molecules strongly interact with polar groups rather than the relative nonpolar groups, the hydrophobicity of the catalyst is related to the amount of Al species in the zeolite [20]. Given the decrease in the Al species of zeolite framework after the hydrothermal treatment obtained from the 29Si NMR analysis (Fig. 2b), the decrease of the Al-O-Si bond explains the increase in hydrophobicity of the hydrothermally treated catalyst. Next, the effect of dealumination on the property of the active site and the state of Pd was investigated by Raman, CO-DRIFTS, and H2-TPR analyses. The Pd species in the zeolite catalyst can occur as PdO nanoparticles or monoatomic Pd ions [21]. The formation of bulk PdO particles was explored by Raman analysis ( Fig. 3). The peak from 450 to 500 cm−1 belongs to the T-O-T vibration in the chabazite zeolite structure. Another peak at 650 cm−1 can be assigned to bulk PdO [22,23]. From the intensity of the PdO peak, it can be inferred that the formation of bulk PdO accelerated in Pd(1)/SSZ-13 (DeAl), while the Pd(1)/SSZ-13 (HTA) catalyst possessed the least amount of PdO. The Pd ion species in the zeolite catalysts were confirmed by the CO-DRIFTS experiment ( Fig. 4). Various peaks from 2100 to 2200 cm−1 were observed, which are reportedly considered to represent CO molecules adsorbed on the Pd ions (Pd2+ or Pd(OH)+) [8,24]. The CO-adsorption peak was hardly observed from Pd(1)/SSZ-13 (DeAl), which indicates the absence of Pd ions in the catalyst. In contrast, the peak intensity of Pd(1)/SSZ-13 (HTA) was higher than that of the pristine catalyst, which implies that the formation of Pd ions was promoted by the hydrothermal treatment after the Pd impregnation [12]. H2-TPR analysis was conducted to further confirm the previous results because PdO nanoparticles and Pd ions can be distinguished from the reduction temperature ( Fig. 5). The sharp peak in the range of 0–50 °C belongs to the reduction of PdO [17]. The formation of PdH x after the reduction of PdO to Pd metal was confirmed from the negative peak near 100 °C, which arises from the decomposition of PdH x [17]. The TPR profiles of the pristine and Pd(1)/SSZ-13 (DeAl) catalysts were similar, although the peak intensity of PdO reduction was slightly higher for the latter. In contrast, the TPR profile of Pd(1)/SSZ-13 (HTA) was completely different from those of the other catalysts. The PdO peak intensity was clearly reduced compared to the other catalysts and a new broad peak appeared in the range of 100–200 °C, which can be ascribed to the reduction of Pd ions [17]. Because the peak area represents the amount of H2 consumed, the PdO/Pdtotal ratio could be calculated from the H2-TPR results ( Table 2). The concentration of PdO was in the order of Pd(1)/SSZ-13 (DeAl) > Pd(1)/SSZ-13 > Pd(1)/SSZ-13 (HTA). Based on previous characterization results, it can be concluded that most of the Pd species existed as PdO in the pristine and Pd(1)/SSZ-13 (DeAl) catalysts, while Pd ions were the major species for Pd(1)/SSZ-13 (HTA). The larger amount of PdO in Pd(1)/SSZ-13 (DeAl) than that in the pristine catalyst can be explained by the NH3-TPD results (Fig. S6). The low-temperature peak at approximately 150 °C can be assigned to weakly bound NH3 species, while the high-temperature peak above 300 °C belongs to the Brønsted acid sites (framework Al sites) [10]. The amount of acid sites significantly decreased after the hydrothermal treatment because a large proportion of the framework Al species was eliminated during aging. Thus, it is reasonable to assume that the formation of Pd ions will be suppressed when Pd is impregnated on the dealuminated zeolite because Brønsted acid sites are required for the stabilization of Pd ions [21]. In contrast to the other catalysts, majority of the Pd species in the Pd(1)/SSZ-13 (HTA) catalyst existed as Pd ions. The mobility of Pd species increases during the hydrothermal treatment (high temperature and humid condition) [12]. Thus, the increase in the number of Pd ions can be explained by the redispersion of PdO nanoparticles to isolated Pd ions during the aging process. Because of the unique microporous structure of SSZ-13, the PdO nanoparticles can exist at different locations: the external zeolite surface and the internal zeolite pores. Therefore, the location of PdO in the Pd(1)/SSZ-13 and Pd(1)/SSZ-13 (DeAl) catalysts was investigated by STEM and XPS analyses. HAADF-STEM and EDX mapping images displayed the location of PdO particles ( Fig. 6). The images of Pd(1)/SSZ-13 clearly displayed finely dispersed PdO particles with smaller particle sizes, while those of Pd(1)/SSZ-13 (DeAl) were strongly agglomerated. By examining multiple STEM images, the average PdO particle sizes for Pd(1)/SSZ-13 and Pd(1)/SSZ-13 (DeAl) are estimated to be 1.7 ± 0.1, and 3.3 ± 0.3 nm, respectively (Fig. S9). Due to the zeolite spatial confinement effect, PdO particles inside the internal zeolite pore tend to have more uniform and smaller particle sizes than those on the external zeolite surface [21]. Thus, considering the differences of PdO particle size and degree of agglomeration on the external zeolite surface, it can be hypothesized that the concentration of external PdO nanoparticles would be higher in Pd(1)/SSZ-13 (DeAl). The location of PdO particles was further supported by XPS analysis ( Fig. 7). The Pd 3d spectra displayed a peak at approximately 336.7 eV, which can be assigned to either PdO or Pd ions because both oxidation states are Pd2+ [25]. The peak positions were similar, but the peak intensity was much higher for Pd(1)/SSZ-13 (DeAl). The surface atomic concentration was calculated from the XPS results ( Table 3). Although the bulk Pd concentrations of the two catalysts obtained from the ICP-AES analysis was similar, the XPS results demonstrated that their surface Pd concentrations were different. The surface Pd concentration of Pd(1)/SSZ-13 (DeAl) was 0.95 %, much higher than that of the pristine catalyst (0.48 %). Thus, it can be assumed that most of the Pd species in Pd(1)/SSZ-13 (DeAl) were exposed at the external zeolite surface. The difference in the location of PdO species can be explained by the hydrophobicity of the zeolite support because it would be more difficult for the Pd precursor solution to penetrate the internal pores of the hydrophobic zeolite [26]. Concluding the abovementioned characterization results, Pd(1)/SSZ-13 catalyst possesses both external and internal PdO nanoparticles, while majority of the Pd species in Pd(1)/SSZ-13 (DeAl) were exposed at the external zeolite surface. 4 Discussion The Pd(1)/SSZ-13 (DeAl) catalyst exhibited superior activity for methane oxidation than that shown by the other Pd/SSZ-13 catalysts, prepared by the dealumination of the SSZ-13 support. However, various catalytic properties were affected by dealumination, including the hydrophobicity of zeolites and the state and location of the Pd species. Thus, to elucidate whether the enhancement in activity was induced by the change in zeolite hydrophobicity, the activities of the zeolite catalysts were evaluated under dry condition when the feed gas did not contain H2O ( Fig. 8). Interestingly, the catalytic activity of Pd(1)/SSZ-13 (DeAl) was superior to that of the pristine catalyst even under dry conditions. The T 50 values of both catalysts increased after the introduction of water, which indicates a decrease in their initial activity ( Table 4). In addition, activation energies were calculated from the Arrhenius plot (Fig. S7). The activation energies under the dry condition were within 107–116 kJ/mol, which significantly increased after the addition of water in the feed (178–194 kJ/mol). This increase indicates that water still inhibited the catalytic activity of Pd(1)/SSZ-13 (DeAl), even though the zeolite surface became more hydrophobic after dealumination. Therefore, it was reasonable to conclude that the hydrophobicity of zeolite was not a key factor in determining the methane-oxidation activity. Meanwhile, it was confirmed from the Raman, CO-DRIFT, and H2-TPR analyses that the state of Pd changed after the hydrothermal treatment. For instance, Pd species mainly existed as Pd ions in the Pd(1)/SSZ-13 (HTA) catalyst, which exhibited extremely low methane-oxidation activity compared to that shown by the other catalysts. Thus, it is reasonable to assume that the isolated Pd ions were not very active for methane oxidation in contrast to the PdO nanoparticles, which is consistent with previous reports [21,27]. Pd–O pairs are active sites for C–H bond activation, which is a rate-determining step for the methane-oxidation reaction [28]. Therefore, it can be concluded that the Pd paired with extra-lattice oxygen (PdO nanoparticle) is more active for the C–H bond cleavage than the Pd paired with the lattice oxygen of zeolite (Pd ion) [21]. Previous characterization results demonstrated that most Pd species existed as PdO in the Pd(1)/SSZ-13 and Pd(1)/SSZ-13 (DeAl) catalysts, although the location of PdO was different. The PdO species in Pd(1)/SSZ-13 (DeAl) were exposed at the zeolite surface, while a portion of the PdO species in Pd(1)/SSZ-13 was encapsulated inside the zeolite pores. The previous catalytic activity test demonstrated that the methane-oxidation activity of Pd(1)/SSZ-13 (DeAl) was superior to that of Pd(1)/SSZ-13. Thus, it is reasonable to assume that the external PdO nanoparticles were more active than the encapsulated PdO. Considering that SSZ-13 is a small-pore zeolite, the size of PdO inside the micropores would be very small compared to that of PdO at the surface. Recently, various groups have reported that highly dispersed Pd species are not active for the methane-oxidation reaction. Goodman et al. claimed that single-atom catalysts are not active for the reaction because a critical ensemble size is required for the adsorption of oxygen and dehydrogenation of methane [29]. In addition, Murata et al. reported that the size of Pd particles and methane-oxidation activity displayed a volcano-shaped curve and 5–10-nm Pd particles exhibited the highest activity [6]. Moreover, the accessibility of the reactant to the active site can be another reason for the low activity of Pd(1)/SSZ-13. Hence, it is reasonable to assume that methane will be more easily adsorbed on the PdO nanoparticles exposed at the zeolite surface, while diffusion to PdO confined within the zeolite pores will be more difficult [30]. To further prove that the property of Pd was a more critical factor for the catalytic activity than zeolite hydrophobicity, we converted the Pd ions in Pd(1)/SSZ-13 (HTA) to PdO nanoparticles by reduction at 400 °C and re-oxidation at 500 °C. Generally, Pd ions are highly dispersed in the zeolite pores and stabilized at the Brønsted acid sites [21]. Therefore, it can be assumed that the Pd ions inside the zeolite pores will be converted to the encapsulated PdO nanoparticles after the mild reduction and re-oxidation process because of the zeolite-confinement effect [31]. Hence, it can be assumed that there will be negligible difference between the hydrophobicity of Pd(1)/SSZ-13 (HTA-400R500C) and Pd(1)/SSZ-13 (DeAl), while the location of PdO will be completely different. Although Pd(1)/SSZ-13 (HTA-400R500C) possessed a hydrophobic surface, its catalytic activity was still inferior to that of Pd(1)/SSZ-13 (DeAl); in fact, it was even lower than that of the pristine catalyst (Fig. S8). Such a low activity further proves that the hydrophobicity was not a critical factor for the catalytic activity and the PdO nanoparticles confined inside the zeolite pores were not very active for the reaction. The inhibition effect of water on the initial methane-oxidation activity was examined from the previous catalytic activity test and activation energy calculations, which demonstrated that the initial activity was still inhibited by water even after dealumination. In addition, the deactivation effect of water on the catalytic stability was investigated by a long-term activity test at 400 °C ( Fig. 9). All catalysts exhibited deactivation, irrespective of the support material (zeolite or alumina). However, the deactivation rate of Pd(1)/SSZ-13 (DeAl) was slightly lower than that of the other catalysts. Pd/Al2O3 catalysts frequently show deactivation in the presence of water [32,33]. However, recent studies demonstrated that the deactivation can be alleviated when Pd is impregnated on the zeolite with a high Si/Al2 ratio or pure silica zeolite (silicalite-1) [34,35]. Thus, it is reasonable to assume that the Al2O3 support or the PdO-Al2O3 interface is responsible for the deactivation. Cui et al. reported that the PdO nanoparticles encapsulated in the zeolite pores are decorated with an Al layer [21]. However, the PdO nanoparticles in Pd(1)/SSZ-13 (DeAl) will be less affected by Al decoration because they are mostly exposed at the external surface and the Si/Al2 ratio significantly increased after dealumination. Therefore, it can be concluded that Pd(1)/SSZ-13 (DeAl) was less vulnerable to deactivation because the PdO nanoparticles exposed at the external zeolite surface were less decorated by Al. 5 Conclusion Dealumination of Pd/SSZ-13 catalysts was conducted by the hydrothermal treatment in order to study the effects of dealumination on the catalytic properties and activities. Pd(1)/SSZ-13 (HTA), prepared by the hydrothermal treatment of the pristine catalyst, displayed extremely low methane-oxidation activity compared to that shown by the other catalysts. In contrast, Pd(1)/SSZ-13 (DeAl), prepared by the hydrothermal treatment of the SSZ-13 support and subsequent Pd impregnation, exhibited enhanced catalytic activity compared to that shown by the pristine catalyst. TGA, H2O adsorption, and DRIFTS analyses showed that the hydrophobicity of zeolite was enhanced after the dealumination process. However, the increase in T 50 and activation energy in the presence of water indicated that the Pd(1)/SSZ-13 (DeAl) catalyst was still inhibited by water and the change in hydrophobicity was not a key factor for activity enhancement. Next, the state of Pd was investigated by Raman, DRIFTS, and H2-TPR analyses. The Pd species mainly existed as PdO in the pristine and Pd(1)/SSZ-13 (DeAl) catalysts, while Pd(1)/SSZ-13 (HTA) contained a large amount of Pd ions. Thus, the inferior activity of Pd(1)/SSZ-13 (HTA) is related to the state of Pd because Pd ions are not active in C–H bond activation in contrast to PdO. Although both the pristine and Pd(1)/SSZ-13 (DeAl) catalysts possessed a large amount of PdO, the location of PdO was different. Most of the PdO in Pd(1)/SSZ-13 (DeAl) was exposed at the external zeolite surface, while Pd(1)/SSZ-13 possessed both external and internal PdO encapsulated in the zeolite pores. Therefore, the activity enhancement observed from Pd(1)/SSZ-13 (DeAl) can be explained by the larger amount of external PdO nanoparticles, which were more active than the encapsulated PdO. In addition, Pd(1)/SSZ-13 (DeAl) was more resistant to deactivation in the long-term activity test because the external PdO nanoparticles were less decorated by Al. In summary, the hydrothermal treatment is not always beneficial for the methane-oxidation activity. Pd should be impregnated after hydrothermally treating the zeolite support in order to synthesize Pd(1)/SSZ-13 (DeAl), a highly active and stable catalyst, for methane combustion. coredata.dc:description: This study investigated the effects of dealumination on Pd/SSZ-13 catalysts for methane combustion. Pd(1)/SSZ-13 (HTA), prepared by treating the catalyst hydrothermally at 750 °C, displayed extremely low catalytic activity. In contrast, Pd(1)/SSZ-13 (DeAl), prepared by treating the SSZ-13 support hydrothermally followed by Pd impregnation, exhibited superior catalytic activity for methane oxidation. Catalytic properties, including zeolite hydrophobicity and Pd location and states, were investigated by using various characterization techniques to clarify the differences between the catalysts. Most Pd species in the Pd/SSZ-13 (HTA) catalyst existed as Pd ions, which were not very active for the reaction. On the contrary, most Pd species in the Pd(1)/SSZ-13 (DeAl) catalyst existed as PdO nanoparticles at the external surface, which were highly active for methane oxidation. The study results suggested that the amount of external PdO nanoparticles should be maximized in order to make Pd/SSZ-13 catalyst highly active for methane combustion, which was achieved by dealuminating the SSZ-13 support before Pd impregnation.
coredata.dc:title: Effects of dealumination on the methane-combustion activity of Pd/SSZ-13 catalysts
